Trying to explain something from memory is a good way to make sure that you are learning it well. Without looking at any notes, can you describe what you have been learning in this lesson?

Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

For questions 1–5, solve each quadratic equation by rewriting it in factored form and using the zero product property.

  1. \(x^2 + 11x + 35 = 7\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.9.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(x = -4\) and \(x = -7\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2− 14x + 20 = -25\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 8.9.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(x = 9\) and \(x = 5\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2− 6x − 52 = -12\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.9.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(x = 10\) and \(x = -4\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2 − x − 64 = -8\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 8.9.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(x = -7\) and \(x = 8\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2 + 9x + 13 = -5\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.9.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(x = -3\) and \(x = -6\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Without graphing, identify the function whose graph has only one zero.

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 8.9.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(f(x) = x^2 − 8x + 16\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Without graphing, identify the function whose graph has only one zero.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.9.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(f(x) = x^2+ 12x + 36\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Without graphing, identify the function whose graph has two zeros.

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 8.9.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(f(x) = x^2− 81\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Without graphing, identify the function whose graph has two zeros.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 8.9.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(f(x) = x^2+ 4x − 21\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Solve the equation: \(x^2− 18x + 90 = 9\).

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 8.9.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(x=9\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?
